prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SR24S in Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose continuum observations in Band 7 of SR24S transition disk. In addition, we would also like to have line observations of molecular gas lines 13CO and C18O (3-2) of this disk.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to spatially resolve the continuum emission of the disk around SR24S in Band 7 (345 GHz), with antenna configurations that give us a spatial resolution ~0.2'' i.e., C34-7 configuration. With this observation and complemented with Band 6 observations on the same source, our main goal is to determine the relative variation of the spectral index of the dust opacity. Therefore, continuum observations at two different millimetre wavelengths with high angular resolution are crucial to detect a size dust distribution in the outer regions of this disk. These two bands are chosen because of the resolution needed to resolve variations in the spectral index map and to ensure optically thin emission from the dust. Therefore, observations at shorter wavelength are avoided because of the potential dust optical depth effects and longer wavelengths bands do not provide the needed resolution to resolve variations of the spectral index. Only Bands 6 and 7 of ALMA in Cycle 2 can provide the resolution and sensitivity needed for the main science goal of this proposal.
In parallel with continuum at these bands, we also want to resolve CO isotopologues, we propose to obtain the abundant molecular gas lines $^{13}$CO and C$^{18}$O 3-2 in Band 7, to have better constraints on the gas density distribution and therefore additional information of the nature of the potential particle traps in these disks. For the spectral line observations, we use two different basebands with a bandwidth of 1875 MHz and resolution of 1.13MHz in FDM mode (spectral averaging factor of 2), for a possible line detection with $\sim$1.0 km s$^{-1}$ resolution.
Our sensitivity requirements are based on our main goal of measuring variations of the spectral index. We expect, on the basis of our theoretical model estimates, that the spectral index changes between 2 and 3.5 along the ring. To achieve this goal we need to be able to discern differences in the spectral index of at least ~0.1. Since $\alpha=(\lg I_7-\lg I_6)/(\lg\nu_7-\lg\nu_6)$, with $I_{7,6}$ the intensity in Bands 7,6, this translates into a relative error tolerance in both $I_7$ and $I_6$ of $\delta I/I\lesssim 0.05$, i.e.\ a SNR of 20. Taking the expected intensity at the point along the ring opposite to the bump (i.e.\ the weakest point on the ring) we arrive at RMS requirements of $\sim$ 0.05 mJy/beam in Band 7 for the continuum. This sensitivity is also enough to confirm any azimuthal variation in the continuum for SR24S disk.
Considering the above RMS estimate and using typical weather conditions for the ALMA sensitivity calculator, we calculate ~20 minutes of on-source integration time in Band 7. This corresponds to a total observing time of 58 minutes for SR24S. With this observing time, we obtain a rms level of $\sim$ 4.0mJy/beam per $\sim$1km/s, which is also enough to detect possible decrements in the gas surface density by observing the mentioned CO isotopologues.
With these observations, we will be able to distinguish any relative dependence of the spectral index (by comparing the value inside and outside the traps) and potential radial decrements of the gas surface density. Our team, made of experts in millimetre interferometric observations and data reduction, as well as in disk modelling: with expertise in both dust motion/growth models and radiative transfer modelling; will be able to analyse the ALMA data, with the models presented in this proposal, to produce and publish immediate breakthrough results.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Circumstellar disks around young stars are known to be the birthplaces of planets. Planet formation starts with the coagulation of dust particles to larger dust aggregates. However, after many decades of research it is still an enigma how Nature manages to overcome the 'meter size barrier'. At sizes beyond about 0.1 millimetre at ~50AU distances, the particles acquire high radial drift velocities and high collision speeds, leading to destruction and loss. In recent years the concept of "particle traps" has gained popularity as a possible solution to this problem: Large scale pressure bumps such as vortices can attract and trap dust particles, and provide a calm localised environment where dust growth proceeds very effectively. This idea can be tested with ALMA in Cycle 2. Our program aims to investigate the process of dust trapping in the transition disks around SR24S and LkHa330. With two ALMA observations per source at 345GHz (Band 7) and at 230GHz (Band 6), we will test the theoretical predictions for the azimuthal profile of the spectral index and the gas density distributions. A confirmation would lend credence to the notion that planetesimals form in very localised 'hotspots'
